en: Interview with Emily Schubert, former artist in residence at Arrowmont, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Schubert discusses her role at Arrowmont before recounting the events of the wildfires. She also details how the event has affected her and her art over the long term. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "I also remember passing like a bunch of just demolished cars. There were a bunch of wrecks because people were rushing so fast. And I remember passing this one like silver sports vehicle and thinking there is no way that the person that was in that car is not hurt because it was just completely--I've never seen a car look at that after a wreck. And you can tell that all the airbags went off, and it caught fire and it was horrible, and it was just like pushed to the side of the road."
Individuals (tourists or locals) directly affected by the fire
Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts

She also details how the event has affected her and her art over the long term. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "I also remember passing like a bunch of just demolished cars. There were a bunch of wrecks because people were rushing so fast. And I remember passing this one like silver sports vehicle and thinking there is no way that the person that was in that car is not hurt because it was just completely--I've never seen a car look at that after a wreck. Interview with Emily Schubert, 2020-07-09 -- Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts
Can you state your name and tell us about yourself?
Can you tell us a little about Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts' mission and what your fellowship entailed? What was your day-to-day?
Can you tell us about the days or weeks leading up to the wildfires?
Walk us through that day of the fires. You said that you were teaching a class of students?
Did the artists needing to drop off pieces seem disturbed at that point?
Did you have to leave things behind at Arrowmont?
How were you able to stay in touch with family and friends during that time?
What did your residency look like after the fire?
What are some of the long-term impacts this event had on you and your work?

seo.title: Interview with Emily Schubert, 2020-07-09 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
seo.description: Interview with Emily Schubert, former artist in residence at Arrowmont, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Schubert discusses her role at Arrowmont before recounting the events of the wildfires. She also details how the event has affected her and her art over the long term. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "I also remember passing like a bunch of just demolished cars. There were a bunch of wrecks because people were rushing so fast. And I remember passing this one like silver sports vehicle and thinking there is no way that the person that was in that car is not hurt because it was just completely--I've never seen a car look at that after a wreck. And you can tell that all the airbags went off, and it caught fire and it was horrible, and it was just like pushed to the side of the road."
